abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Technical Assistance Project
            for the Public and Private Provision of Infrastructure is
            rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and borrower performance as satisfactory.
            Many lessons learned from the project include: Private
            participation in infrastructure development should be
            integrated within the overall infrastructure framework.
            There was resistance to change from the old ways of
            infrastructure development due to fear that the private
            sector will win concessions through corrupt connections and
            exploit consumers by maximizing profits and providing poor
            service. Introducing effective competition and independent
            regulatory bodies working with consumers associations is
            necessary to allay these fear. A public-private partnership
            information center or network will facilitate information
            dissemination. It was clear from the project that
            sub-projects with an enthusiastic and influential supporter
            within the government were much more likely to proceed to
            the physical implementation of infrastructure development.
            These champions can help to overcome government and public
            resistance to private sector participation (PSP) policy.
            There is a need to strengthen and deepen financial markets.
            Continued support for development of the PSP framework is
            needed. Demonstration projects are essential.
